title.text: VTEX System Description for the NLI 2013 Shared Task

abstractContent.text: This paper describes the system developed for the NLI 2013 Shared Task, requiring to identify a writer's native language by some text written in English.
I explore the given manually annotated data using word features such as the length, endings and character trigrams.
Modified TFIDF is used to generate a stop-word list automatically.
The distance between two documents is calculated combining n-grams of word lengths and endings, and character trigrams.

introductionContent.text: Native Language Identification (NLI) is the task of identifying the first spoken language (L1) of a person based on the person's written text in another language.

introductionContent.text: As a natural language processing (NLP) task, it is properly categorized as text classification, and standard approaches like support vector machines (SVM) are successufully applied to it. trained SVM models with a set of stylistic features, including Part of Speech (POS) and character n-grams (sequences), function words, and spelling error types, achieving 80% accuracy in a 5-language task.
showed that syntactic patterns, derived by a parser, are more effective than other stylistic features.
The Cambridge Learner Corpus has been used recently by, who concluded that character n-grams are the most promising features.
investigated function words, character ngrams, POS n-grams, POS/function n-grams, CFG productions, dependencies, word n-grams.
A notable problem in the recent NLI research is a clear interaction between native languages and topics in the corpora.
The solution in the mentioned work was to avoid lexical features that might carry topical information.
